evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP or marking deficiencies were not recognized or relevant in this scope
If communication breakdown evidence was stronger and more relevant than environment/marking deficiency

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7-H9 directly supports availability of the root CS__R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION__R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY within the specified scope, describing TRP location, visual signaling insufficiency, and trainee awareness.

node.statement: The root CS__R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION__R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY fits the key features required for identifying procedural deviations related to environment or marking deficiencies in the specified aircraft context.

assumptions: The TRP and blast barrier location and clearance are considered part of environment or marking features
The lack of effective visual signals and awareness relates to environment or marking deficiency rather than purely communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear communication breakdown as the primary cause rather than environment or marking issues
If the TRP markings and environment were adequate and not contributing to the deviation

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 describe the environment and marking deficiency (TRP and clearance), while H8 and H9 highlight procedural issues related to environment/marking awareness and communication, supporting the fit to key features for environment or marking deficiency rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the relative contribution of communication versus environment/marking deficiencies

node.statement: The root CS__R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION__R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY demonstrates resistance to defeaters by addressing potential counterarguments and ensuring robustness in the context of procedural deviation analysis.

defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and signaling methods were in place and followed, reducing the impact of environment or marking deficiencies, this would challenge the defeater resistance claim.
